metadata.case_name: Amar Singh and four others v. Custodian-General of Evacuee Property

facts.text: Petitioners Amar Singh and four others are displaced persons who owned land in Chak No. 159-RB, Tahsil Jaranwala, District Lyallpur in Pakistan and were co-sharers in joint khata in village Sultanwind, Amritsar.
On displacement, petitioners temporarily allotted agricultural land in Sultanwind; in 1949 allotted total 38 standard acres and 13 units quasi-permanent basis.

Director-General of Relief and Rehabilitation Additional Custodian ordered on January 7, 1950, allotment of 142 standard acres and 5 units of Sultanwind land to allottees of Provincial Gardens, necessitating readjustment of allotments.

Deputy Custodian, Amritsar proposed cancellation of petitioners' allotment on July 31, 1951; approved by Custodian Financial Commissioner, Relief and Rehabilitation on February 6, 1952; passed without notice to petitioners.
Petitioners filed revision under s. 27 Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 before Custodian-General; dismissed by Deputy Custodian-General on May 1, 1954 after hearing parties.

Partition of India on August 15, 1947 led to mass migrations: about 5 million Non-Muslims from West Punjab to East Punjab; displaced persons left 67 lakh acres in Pakistan, evacuees left 47 lakh acres in East Punjab Pepsu.
Government introduced quasi-permanent allotments via Press Communique February 7, 1948; no rights of ownership or permanent occupancy, but possession maintained.
East Punjab Government notification No. 4892/S dated July 8, 1949 set conditions for quasi-permanent allotments of evacuee land to displaced persons.
Petitioners' allotment quasi-permanent; cancellation undisputedly under Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 and rules.
Series of evacuee property laws from 1947: East Punjab Evacuees Administration of Property Ordinance IV of 1947, Act XIV of 1947, amendments, Central Act XXXI of 1950.
Punjab Government notification February 6, 1950 deemed July 8, 1949 conditions as rules under Central Ordinance XXVII of 1949.
Central Rules 1950, Punjab Instructions August 29, 1951 for review revision of allotments.
Amendments to Rule 14 Central Rules via S.R.O. 1290 July 22, 1952, S.R.O. 351 February 13, 1953 restricting cancellation of quasi-permanent rural allotments.
Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954; s.12 acquisition of evacuee property; notification March 24, 1955 acquired most quasi-permanent allotted properties.
Petitioners have not obtained sanad under Displaced Persons Compensation Rules 1955.

legal_issues.text: Whether the rights of a quasi-permanent allottee constitute property within the meaning of Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2) of the Constitution.
Whether the orders of the Custodian and Deputy Custodian-General canceling the quasi-permanent allotment amount to violation of fundamental rights under Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2).

petitioner_arguments.text: Allotment to petitioners was on quasi-permanent basis acquiring rights constituting property; cancellation orders violate fundamental rights to property under Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2); entitled to quash orders and declare rights.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1), 31(2) of Constitution; quasi-permanent allotment scheme

petitioner_arguments.text: Under Displaced Persons Compensation Act 1954 and rules, quasi-permanent allottees entitled to continue possession and obtain transfer sanad as compensation; discretionary power obligatory where conditions exist.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10 Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 1954; r.72(2) Rules 1955; Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford

petitioner_arguments.text: Quasi-permanent allottee treated as owner for various purposes under Punjab laws.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Punjab Land Revenue Act 1887 r.5; East Punjab Holdings Consolidation Act 1948

court_reasoning.text: Detailed historical review of evacuee property laws from 1947 shows allotments are grants of use/occupation, initially temporary, later quasi-permanent but subject to wide cancellation powers by Custodian for administrative reasons; evacuee retains ultimate ownership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Quasi-permanent allotment is provisional interest analogous to jus in re aliena, not property itself; heritability, improvements etc. do not elevate to ownership.

court_reasoning.text: Even post-1952 amendments restrict but do not negate cancellation powers under s.12 Act 1950; Displaced Persons Act 1954 s.10 allows continued possession but subject to s.19 cancellation; no indefeasible right to sanad.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rights subject to exigencies of administration and inter-dominion agreements; unstable bundle not constituting property.

court_reasoning.text: Cancellation under authority of law creating the rights; ss.28,46 Act 1950 bar challenge; no deprivation without authority of law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if erroneous, exercise within jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Interest not acquirable/disposable as property under Art.19(1)(f); not acquisition/requisition under Art.31(2); mere possession not higher.

holdings.text: Rights of quasi-permanent allottee do not constitute property within Arts.19(1)(f), 31(1), 31(2); no violation of fundamental rights by cancellation orders.
Cancellation lawful under Evacuee Property Act; no deprivation without authority of law.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art.32 dismissed holding that quasi-permanent allotment rights do not constitute property protected by fundamental rights; cancellation lawful under Evacuee Property Act.

key_quotes.text: The two substantial questions that arise, therefore, for consideration are (1) whether the rights of a quasi-permanent allottee constitute property within the meaning of the articles above referred to, and (2) whether the orders of the Custodian and Deputy Custodian-General canceling the quasi-permanent allotment amount to violation fundamental rights contemplated by the above articles.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Having given our best consideration, we are unable to hold that the interest of a quasi-permanent allottee is property within the concept of that word so as to attract the protection of fundamental rights.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on nature of quasi-permanent rights.

key_quotes.text: The East Punjab Government propose to replace the present system of temporary allotments of evacuee lands by a new system of allotments which will take account of the holdings of evacuees in West Punjab. The new allotments will not confer rights of ownership or permanent occupancy, but the possession of allottees will be maintained.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes 1948 Press Communique clarifying no ownership rights.
